docs.text: seen august 8 , 1998 at 6 p . m . at rotterdam square cinemas ( rotterdam , ny ) , theater #6 , by myself for free using my sony/loews critic's pass .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: [theater rating : * * * : good seats , sound , and picture]
docs.label: positive

docs.text: war is a topic that can't help but be glorified any way it is portrayed by the media .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: movies , documentaries , and even history books have a way of making the darker side of humanity exciting since the most general aspects are focused on , such as strategy , politics , and victory .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's easy to forget war , in its most basic form , is a battle of armies out to slaughter each other .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: forgotten more easily is the fact that each soldier , no matter what his rank or importance , is a real flesh-and-blood person and not just a number .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " saving private ryan " is one of the few films that dares play up this aspect , especially in its unapologetic , realistic delivery .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it proves there's a huge difference between battling and killing .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film opens with one of the most graphic , disturbing scenes in recent memory .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's world war ii , d-day to be exact , and the u . s . military is invading omaha beach where the nazis are more than ready for them .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: spielberg uses many techniques to create for a total sense of reality .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: instead of positioned cameras , the footage here seems to have been shot by camera operators running alongside soldiers as if they were just as scared .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: there is no sense of stability , but of constant , anxious , and confusing motion , giving us the feeling of being in the middle of the battle , and just a vulnerable as the poor troops .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " poor " is a proper word to describe how pathetic and yet innocent the men fighting are .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: there is little to no dialogue throughout the loud battle and no prologue to define any characters .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: we don't get the feeling these are handsome actors playing heroic roles , but that these are men about to kill and be killed for reasons beyond their understanding .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the nazis are not portrayed as enemies to be hated , but as people that must be destroyed because they're there .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in the movies , the good guys can run through a firestorm of bullets and bombs and not get a scratch , but in reality that wouldn't happen .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the men have nothing to shield or protect them besides some metal flanks and dead bodies .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: they are sitting ducks and we realize this through the perspective of the well-secured germans who can actually see who , what , and where they're shooting , unlike the americans who must fire in a general direction to avoid getting their heads blown off .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: perhaps the film is flawed by not providing any backstory on the war itself and who the men really are , but that seems to be part of the theme .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film seems to rely on the audience's sense of patriotism , that the american military is " right " and good and that the nazis are " inherently evil . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the battle scene eventually focuses on a group of men who have miraculously survived and made their way close to the enemy stronghold ( a whole 50-foot progression ) , and begin to inflict some damage .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i have to admit that once the first glimpse of victory over the nazis sprang up , i couldn't help but feel some sense of joy and relief .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: to triumph against all odds is a cliche to be sure , but there's nothing cliche about the graphic , detailed , atmosphere here because it really happened .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: one of the most surprising aspects of the film is how little story construction there is , and yet the events that take place make sense and are interesting .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the plot is practically irrelevant since the film is more concerned with the reality of the war and the soldiers we meet .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: tom hanks stars as captain miller , a relatively average man who happens to be the leader of a platoon .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he's never obsessive or any such generic , cartoonish characteristic that might dominate a character like this .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he doesn't want to be there any more than his men , but when he is given a mission he intends to carry it out .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the mission the film is concerned with is , as the title states , saving private ryan .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: through a series of command started by an ordinary clerical worker , it is brought to a general's attention that three brothers from iowa have been killed in action and their mother will receive notices of each's death simultaneously .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when they learn a fourth brother is stationed somewhere in europe , they make it a top priority to have him returned safely to his mother .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's easy to sympathize with this situation , after all , no one should have to lose all their children at once .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but finding one man in this war is , as miller puts it , " like trying to find a needle in a stack of needles . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the saving of private ryan isn't just a dramatic device , but a thematic one .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his salvation represents the sense of innocence the country , the world even , was trying to convince itself it still had .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when miller's company hears of the mission , they scoff at the idea assuming he is dead , but miller isn't so quick to shrug it off .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he knows the only thing that can really save soldiers from death is hope , and now he has the opportunity to make someone's sense of hope a reality .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the mission to find ryan gives miller's group a destination , but not direction .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: along the way many things happen to them , both good and bad .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a few battles are fought , not to be major accomplishments for the war , but because they encounter german soldiers and have no other choice .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the act of killing itself becomes one of the film's major philosophical metaphors .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the soldiers don't mind killing other soldiers in blind battle , but when they come across a lone survivor who begs them to let him go , they can barely stop themselves from killing him in cold blood as some kind of vengeance for their losses .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: unfortunately , death is a fact of war , and most films try to avoid it when it comes to the main characters , but here spielberg doesn't want us to think these men are invincible .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in fact , only a small amount of color and personality is sketched into each man , and the performances are good enough to make this method work .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: although the characters are somewhat typical , the actors maintain control over the material at all time .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: whether they're arguing with each other , telling stories of back home , or fighting the germans , they never go overboard and always seem believable .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: sure , there's a zinger here and there , but war doesn't change the fact boys will be boys .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if and when one dies we too can feel the loss , even though we hardly knew them .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the final act brings the story full circle with another tremendous , violent battle sequence .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: private ryan has been found , but facing four to one odds , can the americans defeat the germans and keep ryan alive ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: that's not a premise for thrills , it's symbolic of everything the film has worked for .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it would be wrong to say the film has either a happy or sad ending , it ends the way it must end .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i remember reading a " calvin & hobbes " comic strip where calvin asked his dad something like , " dad , how do armies of men killing each other solve problems ? "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " saving private ryan " is the adult version of that question .
docs.label: positive
